name: Lab 04 Q10 - Use type on cat with the -a option.
description:
### Lab 04: Search Tools

Difficulty: **Beginner**

Task: Use type on cat with the -a option.

Expected behavior: Tail is hashed. What this means is tail is an external command in the file system and it has been stored in the shell's hash table. If the command is run again the shell will execute it without having to search for it in the directories in the PATH environmental variable. You can also use the -a option with the type utility to return all instances of the specified command in the file system. Enter " type -a cat " at the prompt.

name: Lab 12 Q15 - Learn bash history shortcuts
description:
### Lab 12: History

Difficulty: **Intermediate**

Task: Learn bash history shortcuts

Expected behavior: Looks like we need to use sudo to read the file. Luckily, there are a few shortcuts we can use so that we don't need to retype the whole command. Bash will replace " !! " with the last command you entered, so you can run sudo !! to run the previous command as sudo. If you ran a command after that command, you can run sudo !-2 . The " -2 " means to replace it with the command run two commands ago. If you run " history ", you will notice a number before each command. Bash will replace " !<history_number> " with the corresponding command in history. Lastly, you can run sudo !cat and Bash will replace !cat with the last command that began with cat . Use any of these methods to run the previous command with sudo . Enter "student" as the password.

Environment: terminal access is provided in-platform.

name: Lab 18 Q02 - Change the umask .
description:
### Lab 18: Special Permissions

Difficulty: **Intermediate**

Task: Change the umask .

Expected behavior: You need to create several Research and Development documents in the RandD directory. However, you need to make sure these documents are secure from prying eyes. Recall from the permissions lab that Others is automatically granted read access to files when you create them. You don't want this to happen. You need Others to have no access at all to any documents created. Change the default umask by entering " umask 027 ". This will not disable any permissions (0) for the owner leaving the permissions at the default 6 (read and write) for files and 7 (read, write, and execute) for directories. The new umask will disable write (2) for the group permissions making the new permissions 4 (read) for files and 5 (read and execute) for directories. The new umask will disable all permissions (7) for others.

Environment: terminal access is provided in-platform.

Runtime container: `ctfd-linux-lab-base:latest`

Lab reference: `LAB-18`
hints: [{"content": "Focus on the Linux utility implied by the task wording.", "cost": 10}, {"content": "Start by checking manual/help for `change`.", "cost": 25}]

name: Lab 18 Q06 - Set the sticky bit on the RandD directory.
description:
### Lab 18: Special Permissions

Difficulty: **Intermediate**

Task: Set the sticky bit on the RandD directory.

Expected behavior: In the permissions lab, we granted Owner and Group rwx permissions to the RandD directory. However, having the write permission to the directory allows anyone in the research group to delete any file in the directory. We want to configure the directory so that users in the research group can only delete files they actually own. Add the Sticky Bit permission to the RandD directory by entering " chmod 1770 /RandD ". The SUID permission has a default value of 4, the SGID has a default value of 2, and the Sticky Bit has a default value of 1. The 1 in the 1770 is turning the Sticky Bit permission on for the RandD directory.

Environment: terminal access is provided in-platform.

Runtime container: `ctfd-linux-lab-base:latest`

Lab reference: `LAB-18`
hints: [{"content": "Focus on the Linux utility implied by the task wording.", "cost": 10}, {"content": "Start by checking manual/help for `set`.", "cost": 25}]

name: Lab 27 Q07 - Set up local port forwarding.
description:
### Lab 27: Using SSH

Difficulty: **Advanced**

Task: Set up local port forwarding.

Expected behavior: The command should have failed. Your machine doesn't know what " target " is, but ssh-server does. To access target we need to tunnel through ssh-server . Run ssh -4 -f -N -L 1234:target:22 user@ssh-server . The " -4 " option means to use IPv4, the " -f " means to put the command in the background, the " -N " means don't run a command, and the " -L " means to use local port forwarding.

Environment: terminal access is provided in-platform.

name: Lab 28 Q07 - Set up local port forwarding.
description:
### Lab 28: Using SSH

Difficulty: **Expert**

Task: Set up local port forwarding.

Expected behavior: The command should have failed. Your machine doesn't know what " target " is, but ssh-server does. To access target we need to tunnel through ssh-server . Run ssh -4 -f -N -L 1234:target:22 user@ssh-server . The " -4 " option means to use IPv4, the " -f " means to put the command in the background, the " -N " means don't run a command, and the " -L " means to use local port forwarding.

Environment: terminal access is provided in-platform.

name: Lab 33 Q08 - Making a banner, part deux
description:
### Lab 33: System Administration

Difficulty: **Expert**

Task: Making a banner, part deux

Expected behavior: That is the first step, now you need to modify the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file using the following sed one-liner command: sudo sed -i "s/#Banner none/Banner \/etc\/issue\.net/g" /etc/ssh/sshd_config . This command will search the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file for " #Banner " and replace it with " Banner /etc/issue.net " without ever opening the file. This is a functionality of sed, an in-place modification of a file. The Banner portion of the sshd_config file points to a file anywhere on the file system that you want to use as a banner.

Environment: terminal access is provided in-platform.

Runtime container: `ctfd-linux-lab-base:latest`
